\subsubsection{Affichage}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:affichage}}\label{\detokenize{overview/display::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
The basic concept of \sphinxstyleemphasis{display} in LittlevGL is explained in the {[}Porting{]}(/porting/display) section. So before reading further, please read the {[}Porting{]}(/porting/display) section first.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

In LittlevGL, you can have multiple displays, each with their own driver and objects.

Creating more displays is easy: just initialize more display buffers and register another driver for every display.
When you create the UI, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default(disp)}} to tell the library which display to create objects on.

Why would you want multi-display support? Here are some examples:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Have a “normal” TFT display with local UI and create “virtual” screens on VNC on demand. (You need to add your VNC driver).

\item {} 
Avoir un grand écran TFT et un petit écran monochrome.

\item {} 
Have some smaller and simple displays in a large instrument or technology.

\item {} 
Have two large TFT displays: one for a customer and one for the shop assistant.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Utiliser un seul affichage}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:utiliser-un-seul-affichage}}
Using more displays can be useful, but in most cases, it’s not required. Therefore, the whole concept of multi-display is completely hidden if you register only one display.
By default, the lastly created (the only one) display is used as default.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(scr)}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_top()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_sys()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_HOR\_RES}} et\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ LV\_VER\_RES}} sont toujours appliqués sur l’affichage créé en dernier (par défaut).
If you pass \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}} parameter to display related function, usually the default display will be used.
P.ex. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_trig\_activity(NULL)}} déclenchera une activité utilisateur sur l’affichage par défaut (voir ci-dessous dans {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/display:inactivite}]{\emph{Inactivité}}}).


\paragraph{Affichage miroir}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:affichage-miroir}}
To mirror the image of the display to another display, you don’t need to use the multi-display support. Just transfer the buffer received in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{drv.flush\_cb}} to another display too.


\paragraph{Division d’image}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:division-d-image}}
You can create a larger display from smaller ones. You can create it as below:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Set the resolution of the displays to the large display’s resolution.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{drv.flush\_cb}}, truncate and modify the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{area}} parameter for each display.

\item {} 
Send the buffer’s content to each display with the truncated area.

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Ecrans}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:ecrans}}
Every display has each set of \sphinxhref{overview/object\#screen-the-most-basic-parent}{Screens} and the object on the screens.

Be sure not to confuse displays and screens:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Displays} are the physical hardware drawing the pixels.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Screens} are the high-level root objects associated with a particular display. One display can have multiple screens associated with it, but not vice versa.

\end{itemize}

Screens can be considered the highest level containers which have no parent.
The screen’s size is always equal to its display and size their position is (0;0). Therefore, the screens coordinates can’t be changed, i.e. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_pos()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_size()}} or similar functions can’t be used on screens.

A screen can be created from any object type but, the two most typical types are the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Base object}}}} and the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} (to create a wallpaper).

To create a screen, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_t * scr = lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}\_create(NULL, copy)}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{copy}} can be an other screen to copy it.

To load a screen, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(scr)}}. To get the active screen, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}. These functions works on the default display. If you want to to specify which display to work on, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_get\_scr\_act(disp)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_load\_scr(disp, scr)}}.

Screens can be deleted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del(scr)}}, but ensure that you do not delete the currently loaded screen.


\subparagraph{Ecran opaque}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:ecran-opaque}}
Usually, the opacity of the screen is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_COVER}} to provide a solid background for its children.

However, in some special cases, you might want a transparent screen. For example, if you have a video player that renders video frames on a lower layer, you want to create an OSD menu on the upper layer (over the video) using LittlevGL.

To do this, the screen should have a style that sets \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body.opa}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{image.opa}} to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} (or another non-opaque value) to make the screen opaque.

Also, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_SCREEN\_TRANSP}} needs to be enabled. Please note that it only works with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH = 32}}.

The Alpha channel of 32-bit colors will be 0 where there are no objects and will be 255 where there are solid objects.


\paragraph{Fonctionnalités des affichages}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:fonctionnalites-des-affichages}}

\subparagraph{Inactivité}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:inactivite}}
The user’s inactivity is measured on each display. Every use of an {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input device}}}} (if \sphinxhref{/porting/indev\#other-features}{associated with the display}) counts as an activity.
To get time elapsed since the last activity, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_get\_inactive\_time(disp)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is passed, the overall smallest inactivity time will be returned from all displays (\sphinxstylestrong{not the default display}).

You can manually trigger an activity using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_trig\_activity(disp)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}} is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}, the default screen will be used (\sphinxstylestrong{and not all displays}).


\paragraph{Couleurs}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:couleurs}}
The color module handles all color-related functions like changing color depth, creating colors from hex code, converting between color depths, mixing colors, etc.

Les types de variable suivants sont définis par le module couleur :
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color1\_t} Store monochrome color. For compatibility, it also has R, G, B fields but they are always the same value (1 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color8\_t} A structure to store R (3 bit),G (3 bit),B (2 bit) components for 8-bit colors (1 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color16\_t} A structure to store R (5 bit),G (6 bit),B (5 bit) components for 16-bit colors (2 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color32\_t} A structure to store R (8 bit),G (8 bit), B (8 bit) components for 24-bit colors (4 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color\_t} Equivaut à \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color1/8/16/24\_t}} selon le paramètre de profondeur de couleur

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color\_int\_t} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint16\_t}} ou \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint32\_t}} selon le paramètre de profondeur de couleur. Utilisé pour construire des tableaux de couleurs à partir de valeurs numériques.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_opa\_t} Un simple type \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}} pour définir l’opacité.

\end{itemize}

Les types \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}},\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ lv\_color1\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color8\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color16\_t}} et \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color32\_t}} ont quatre champs :
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ch.red} canal rouge

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ch.green} canal vert

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ch.blue} canal bleu

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{full} rouge + vert + bleu en une seule valeur

\end{itemize}

You can set the current color depth in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}, by setting the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} define to 1 (monochrome), 8, 16 or 32.


\subparagraph{Conversion de couleur}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:conversion-de-couleur}}
You can convert a color from the current color depth to another. The converter functions return with a number, so you have to use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{full}} field:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{red}   \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x38}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{green} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x70}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{blue}  \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0xCC}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color1\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c1}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/* Retourne 1 pour les couleurs claires, 0 pour les couleurs sombres */}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c8}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c8}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to8}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Give a 8 bit number with the converted color*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color16\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c16}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c16}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to16}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/* Donne un nombre de 16 bits avec la couleur convertie */}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c32}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c32}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to32}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/* Donne un nombre de 32 bits avec la couleur convertie */}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{Permutation 16 bits}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:permutation-16-bits}}
You may set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_16\_SWAP}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} to swap the bytes of \sphinxstyleemphasis{RGB565} colors. It’s useful if you send the 16-bit colors via a byte-oriented interface like SPI.

As 16-bit numbers are stored in Little Endian format (lower byte on the lower address), the interface will send the lower byte first. However, displays usually need the higher byte first. A mismatch in the byte order will result in highly distorted colors.


\subparagraph{Créer et mélanger les couleurs}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:creer-et-melanger-les-couleurs}}
You can create colors with the current color depth using the LV\_COLOR\_MAKE macro. It takes 3 arguments (red, green, blue) as 8-bit numbers.
For example to create light red color: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_color = COLOR\_MAKE(0xFF,0x80,0x80)}}.

Les couleurs peuvent aussi être créées à partir de codes hexadécimaux : \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_color = lv\_color\_hex(0x288ACF)}} ou \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_color = lv\_color\_hex(0x28C)}}.

Mixing two colors is possible with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mixed\_color = lv\_color\_mix(color1, color2, ratio)}}. Ration can be 0..255. 0 results fully color2, 255 result fully color1.

Colors can be created with from HSV space too using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_hsv\_to\_rgb(hue, saturation, value)}} . \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hue}} should be in 0..360 range, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{saturation}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value}} in 0..100 range.


\subparagraph{Opacité}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:opacite}}
To describe opacity the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}} type is created as a wrapper to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}. Some defines are also introduced:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP} Value: 0, means the opacity makes the color completely transparent

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_10} Valeur : 25, signifie que la couleur est un peu couvrante

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_20 … OPA\_80} viennent logiquement

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_90} Value: 229, means the color near completely covers

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_COVER} Value: 255, means the color completely covers

\end{itemize}

You can also use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_*}} defines in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_mix()}} as a \sphinxstyleemphasis{ratio}.

\subsubsection{Polices}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:polices}}\label{\detokenize{overview/font::doc}}
In LittlevGL fonts are collections of bitmaps and other information required to render the images of the letters (glyph). A font is stored in a \sphinxstylestrong{lv\_font\_t} variable and can be set in style’s \sphinxstyleemphasis{text.font} field. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{font} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}roboto\PYGZus{}28}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit une police plus grande */}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The fonts have a \sphinxstylestrong{bpp (bits per pixel)} property. It shows how many bits are used to describe a pixel in the font. The value stored for a pixel determines the pixel’s opacity.
This way, with higher \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp}, the edges of the letter can be smoother. The possible \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} values are 1, 2, 4 and 8 (higher value means better quality).

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} also affects the required memory size to store the font. For example, \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 4} makes the font nearly 4 times greater compared to \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 1}.


\paragraph{Support Unicode}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:support-unicode}}
LittlevGL supports \sphinxstylestrong{UTF-8} encoded Unicode characters.
You need to configure your editor to save your code/text as UTF-8 (usually this the default) and be sure that, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_TXT\_ENC}} is set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_TXT\_ENC\_UTF8}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. (This is the default value)

Pour le vérifier, essayez

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{label1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If all works well, a \(\checkmark\) character should be displayed.


\paragraph{Polices intégrées}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:polices-integrees}}
There are several built-in fonts in different sizes, which can be enabled in lv\_conf.h by \sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_FONT\_…} defines:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_12}} 12 px

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_16}} 16 px

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_22}} 22 px

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_28}} 28 px

\end{itemize}

The built-in fonts are \sphinxstylestrong{global variables} with names like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_roboto\_16}} for 16 px hight font. To use them in a style, just add a pointer to a font variable like shown above.

Les polices intégrées ont \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 4}, contiennent les caractères ASCII et utilisent la police \sphinxhref{https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Roboto}{Roboto}.

In addition to the ASCII range, the following symbols are also added to the built-in fonts from the \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/}{FontAwesome} font.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{symbols}.png}

Les symboles peuvent être utilisés ainsi :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Ou avec des chaînes :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Apply}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Ou plusieurs symboles ensemble :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}WIFI} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}PLAY}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Special features}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:special-features}}

\subparagraph{Bidirectional support}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:bidirectional-support}}
Most of the languages use Left-to-Right (LTR for short) writing direction, however some languages (such as Hebrew) uses Right-to-Left (RTL for short) direction.

LittlevGL not only supports RTL texts but supports mixed (a.k.a. bidirectional, BiDi) text rendering too. Some examples:

\sphinxincludegraphics{{bidi}.png}

The BiDi support can be enabled by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_BIDI}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}

All texts have a base direction (LTR or RTL) which determines some rendering rules and the default alignment of the text (Left or Right).
However, in LittlevGL, base direction is not only for labels. It’s a general property which can be set for every object.
If unset then it will be inherited from the parent.
So it’s enough to set the base direction of the screen and every object will inherit it.

The default base direction of screen can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_BASE\_DIR\_DEF}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

To set an object’s base direction use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_base\_dir(obj, base\_dir)}}.  The possible base direction are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_LTR}}: Left to Right base direction

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_RTL}}: Right to Left base direction

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_AUTO}}: Auto detect base direction

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_INHERIT}}: Inherit the base direction from the parent (default for non-screen objects)

\end{itemize}

This list summarizes the effect of RTL base direction on objects:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Create objects by default on the right

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tabview}}: displays tabs from right to left

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb}}: Show the box on the right

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm}}: Show buttons from right to left

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list}}: Show the icon on the right

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist}}: Align the options to the right

\item {} 
The texts in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_table}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tabview}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_roller}} are processed to display correctly with RTL parts too

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Subpixel rendering}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:subpixel-rendering}}
Subpixel rendering means to increase the horizontal resolution by rendering on Red, Green and Blue channel instead of pixel level. It results in higher quality letter anti-alaising.

Subpixel rendering requires to generate the fonts with special settings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In the online converter tick the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Subpixel}} box

\item {} 
In the command line tool use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-{-}lcd}} flag. Note that the generated font needs about 3 times more memory.

\end{itemize}

Subpixel rendering works only if the color channels of the pixels have a horizontal layout. That is the R, G, B channels are next eachother and not above eachother.
The order of color channels also needs to match with the library settings. By default the LittlevGL assumes \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RGB}} order, however it can ba swapped by setting \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SUBPX\_BGR  1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\subparagraph{Compress fonts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:compress-fonts}}
The bitmaps of the fonts can be compressed by
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
ticking the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Compressed}} check box in the online converter

\item {} 
not passing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-{-}no-compress}}flag to the offline converter (applies compression by default)

\end{itemize}

The compression is more effective with larger fonts and higher bpp. However, it’s about 30\% slower to render the compressed fonts.
Therefore it’s recommended to compress only the largest fonts of user interface, because
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
they need the most memory

\item {} 
they can be compressed better

\item {} 
and probably they are used less frequently then the medium sized fonts. (so performance cost is smaller)

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Ajouter une nouvelle police}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:ajouter-une-nouvelle-police}}
Il y a plusieurs manières d’ajouter une nouvelle police à votre projet :
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
The simplest method is to use the \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/ttf-font-to-c-array}{Online font converter}. Just set the parameters, click the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Convert} button, copy the font to your project and use it. \sphinxstylestrong{Be sure to carefully read the steps provided on that site or you will get an error while converting.}

\item {} 
Utilisez le {[}Convertisseur de polices hors ligne{]} (https://github.com/littlevgl/lv\_font\_conv) (nécessite l’installation de Node.js).

\item {} 
If you want to create something like the built-in fonts (Roboto font and symbols) but in different size and/or ranges, you can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{built\_in\_font\_gen.py}} script in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/scripts/built\_in\_font}} folder.
(It requires Python and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_conv}} to be installed)

\end{enumerate}

To declare the font in a file, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_DECLARE(my\_font\_name)}}.

To make the fonts globally available (like the builtin fonts), add them to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_CUSTOM\_DECLARE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\paragraph{Ajouter de nouveaux symboles}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:ajouter-de-nouveaux-symboles}}
The built-in symbols are created from \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/}{FontAwesome} font.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Search symbol on \sphinxurl{https://fontawesome.com}. For example the \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/icons/usb?style=brands}{USB symbol}. Copy it’s Unicode ID which is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0xf287}} in this case.

\item {} 
Open the \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/ttf-font-to-c-array}{Online font converter}. Add Add \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/tools/FontAwesome5-Solid+Brands+Regular.woff}{FontAwesome.woff}. .

\item {} 
Set the parameters such as Name, Size, BPP. You’ll use this name to declare and use the font in your code.

\item {} 
Add the Unicode ID of the symbol to the range field. E.g.\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ 0xf287}} for the USB symbol. More symbols can be enumerated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{,}}.

\item {} 
Convert the font and copy it to your project. Make sure to compile the .c file of your font.

\item {} 
Declare the font using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{extern lv\_font\_t my\_font\_name;}} or simply \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_DECLARE(my\_font\_name);}}.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxstylestrong{Using the symbol}
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Convert the Unicode value to UTF8. You can do it e.g on \sphinxhref{http://www.ltg.ed.ac.uk/\%7Erichard/utf-8.cgi?input=f287\&mode=hex}{this site}. For \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0xf287}} the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Hex UTF-8 bytes} are \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EF 8A 87}}.

\item {} 
Create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{define}} from the UTF8 values: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#define MY\_USB\_SYMBOL "\textbackslash{}xEF\textbackslash{}x8A\textbackslash{}x87"}}

\item {} 
Create a label and set the text. Eg. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, MY\_USB\_SYMBOL)}}

\end{enumerate}

Note - \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, MY\_USB\_SYMBOL)}} searches for this symbol in the font defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text.font}} properties. To use the symbol you may need to change it. Eg \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ style.text.font = my\_font\_name}}


\paragraph{Ajouter un nouveau moteur de polices}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:ajouter-un-nouveau-moteur-de-polices}}
LittlevGL’s font interface is designed to be very flexible.
You don’t need to use LittlevGL’s internal font engine but, you can add your own.
For example, use \sphinxhref{https://www.freetype.org/}{FreeType} to real-time render glyphs from TTF fonts or use an external flash to store the font’s bitmap and read them when the library needs them.

Pour ce faire, une variable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_t}} personnalisée doit être créée :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/* Décrit les propriétés d\PYGZsq{}une police */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit une fonction de rappel pour obtenir des informations sur les glyphes */}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}bitmap} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}bitmap\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit une fonction de rappel pour obtenir l\PYGZsq{}image matricielle d\PYGZsq{}un glyphe */}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{line\PYGZus{}height} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{height}\PYG{p}{;}                       \PYG{c+cm}{/* La hauteur réelle de la ligne où le texte s\PYGZsq{}inscrit */}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}line} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}line}\PYG{p}{;}                      \PYG{c+cm}{/* La ligne de base mesurée à partir du haut de la ligne */}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}required}\PYG{p}{;}                   \PYG{c+cm}{/*  Enregistre ici toutes les données spécifiques à l\PYGZsq{}implémentation */}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}                      \PYG{c+cm}{/* Éventuellement des données utilisateur supplémentaires */}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* Get info about glyph of {}`unicode\PYGZus{}letter{}` in {}`font{}` font.}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Enregistre le résultat dans {}`dsc\PYGZus{}out{}`.}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * La lettre suivante ({}`unicode\PYGZus{}letter\PYGZus{}next{}`) peut être utilisée pour calculer la largeur requise par ce glyphe (crénage)}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{const} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{font}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{unicode\PYGZus{}letter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{unicode\PYGZus{}letter\PYGZus{}next}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+cm}{/* Votre code ici */}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/* Enregistre le résultat.}
\PYG{c+cm}{     * For example ...}
\PYG{c+cm}{     */}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{adv\PYGZus{}w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/* Espace horizontal requis par le glyphe en [px] */}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{box\PYGZus{}h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/* Hauteur de l\PYGZsq{}image en [px] */}

\subsubsection{Images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:images}}\label{\detokenize{overview/image::doc}}
An image can be a file or variable which stores the bitmap itself and some metadata.


\paragraph{Enregistrer des images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:enregistrer-des-images}}
Vous pouvez enregistrer des images à deux endroits
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
en tant que variable en mémoire interne (MEV ou MEM)

\item {} 
as a file

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Variables}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:variables}}
The images stored internally in a variable is composed mainly of an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t}} structure with the following fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{header}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{cf} Format de couleur. Voir {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:formats-de-couleur}]{\emph{ci-dessous}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{w} largeur en pixels (\textless{}= 2048)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{h} hauteur en pixels (\textless{}= 2048)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{always zero} 3 bits qui doivent toujours être à zéro

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{reserved} réservé pour une utilisation future

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{data}pointeur sur un tableau où l’image elle-même est enregistrée

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{data\_size} length of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data}} in bytes

\end{itemize}

These are usually stored within a project as C files. They are linked into the resulting executable like any other constant data.


\subparagraph{Fichiers}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:fichiers}}
To deal with files you need to add a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} to LittlevGL. In short, a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} is a collection of functions (\sphinxstyleemphasis{open}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{read}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{close}, etc.) registered in LittlevGL to make file operations.
You can add an interface to a standard file system (FAT32 on SD card) or you create your simple file system to read data from an SPI Flash memory.
In every case, a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} is just an abstraction to read and/or write data to a memory.
See the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{File system}}}} section to learn more.

Images stored as files are not linked into the resulting executable, and must be read to RAM before being drawn. As a result, they are not as resource-friendly as variable images. However, they are easier to replace without needing to recompile the main program.


\paragraph{Formats de couleur}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:formats-de-couleur}}
Divers formats de couleur intégrés sont pris en charge:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR} Simply stores the RGB colors (in whatever color depth LittlevGL is configured for).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA} Like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} but it also adds an alpha (transparency) byte for every pixel.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_CHROMA\_KEYED} Like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} but if a pixel has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} (set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}) color the pixel will be transparent.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_1/2/4/8BIT} Uses a palette with 2, 4, 16 or 256 colors and stores each pixel in 1, 2, 4 or 8 bits.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_1/2/4/8BIT} \sphinxstylestrong{Only stores the Alpha value on 1, 2, 4 or 8 bits.} The pixels take the color of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.image.color}} and the set opacity. The source image has to be an alpha channel. This is ideal for bitmaps similar to fonts (where the whole image is one color but you’d like to be able to change it).

\end{itemize}

The bytes of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} images are stored in the following order.

For 32-bit color depth:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Bleu

\item {} 
Byte 1: Vert

\item {} 
Byte 2: Rouge

\item {} 
Byte 3: Alpha

\end{itemize}

For 16-bit color depth:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Green 3 lower bit, Blue 5 bit

\item {} 
Byte 1: Rouge 5 bits, Vert 3 bits de poids fort

\item {} 
Byte 2: octet Alpha (seulement avec LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)

\end{itemize}

For 8-bit color depth:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Rouge 3 bits, Vert 3 bits, Bleu 2 bits

\item {} 
Byte 2: octet Alpha (seulement avec LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)

\end{itemize}

You can store images in a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} format to indicate that, it’s not a built-in color format and an external {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:image-decoder}]{\emph{Image decoder}}} needs to be used to decode the image.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW} Indicates a basic raw image (e.g. a PNG or JPG image).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_ALPHA} Indicates that the image has alpha and an alpha byte is added for every pixel.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_CHROME\_KEYED} Indicates that the image is chrome keyed as described in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_CHROMA\_KEYED}} above.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Ajouter et utiliser des images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:ajouter-et-utiliser-des-images}}
Vous pouvez ajouter des images à LittlevGL de deux manières :
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
using the online converter

\item {} 
créer manuellement des images

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Convertisseur en ligne}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:convertisseur-en-ligne}}
The online Image converter is available here: https://littlevgl.com/image-to-c-array

Adding an image to LittlevGL via online converter is easy.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
You need to select a \sphinxstyleemphasis{BMP}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{PNG} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{JPG} image first.

\item {} 
Give the image a name that will be used within LittlevGL.

\item {} 
Select the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}]{\emph{Color format}}}.

\item {} 
Select the type of image you want. Choosing a binary will generate a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.bin}} file that must be stored separately and read using the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:files}]{\emph{file support}}}. Choosing a variable will generate a standard C file that can be linked into your project.

\item {} 
Hit the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Convert} button. Once the conversion is finished, your browser will automatically download the resulting file.

\end{enumerate}

In the converter C arrays (variables), the bitmaps for all the color depths (1, 8, 16 or 32) are included in the C file, but only the color depth that matches \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} will actually be linked into the resulting executable.

In case of binary files, you need to specify the color format you want:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
RGB332 for 8-bit color depth

\item {} 
RGB565 for 16-bit color depth

\item {} 
RGB565 Swap for 16-bit color depth (two bytes are swapped)

\item {} 
RGB888 for 32-bit color depth

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Créer une image manuellement}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:creer-une-image-manuellement}}
If you are generating an image at run-time, you can craft an image variable to display it using LittlevGL. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{uint8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+m+mh}{0x00}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x01}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x02}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{always\PYGZus{}zero} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}DEPTH} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{cf} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}CF\PYGZus{}TRUE\PYGZus{}COLOR}\PYG{p}{,}          \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit le format de couleur */}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If the color format is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA}} you can set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_size}} like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{80 * 60 * LV\_IMG\_PX\_SIZE\_ALPHA\_BYTE}}.

Another (possibly simpler) option to create and display an image at run-time is to use the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/canvas::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Canvas}}}} object.


\subparagraph{Utiliser des images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:utiliser-des-images}}
The simplest way to use an image in LittlevGL is to display it with an {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_img}}}} object:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{icon} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* A partir d\PYGZsq{}une variable */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{icon}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}icon\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* A partir d\PYGZsq{}un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{icon}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{S:my\PYGZus{}icon.bin}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If the image was converted with the online converter, you should use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_DECLARE(my\_icon\_dsc)}} to declare the image in the file where you want to use it.


\paragraph{Décodeur d’images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:decodeur-d-images}}
As you can see in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}]{\emph{Color formats}}} section, LittlevGL supports several built-in image formats. In many cases, these will be all you need. LittlevGL doesn’t directly support, however, generic image formats like PNG or JPG.

To handle non-built-in image formats, you need to use external libraries and attach them to LittlevGL via the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Image decoder} interface.

The image decoder consists of 4 callbacks:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{info} get some basic info about the image (width, height and color format).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{open} open the image: either store the decoded image or set it to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} to indicate the image can be read line-by-line.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{read} if \sphinxstyleemphasis{open} didn’t fully open the image this function should give some decoded data (max 1 line) from a given position.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{close} ferme l’image ouverte, libére les ressources allouées.

\end{itemize}

You can add any number of image decoders. When an image needs to be drawn, the library will try all the registered image decoder until finding one which can open the image, i.e. knowing that format.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_...}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_INDEXED\_...}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_ALPHA\_...}} formats (essentially, all non-\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RAW}} formats) are understood by the built-in decoder.


\subparagraph{Formats d’image personnalisés}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:formats-d-image-personnalises}}
The easiest way to create a custom image is to use the online image converter and set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw with alpha}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw with chrome keyed}} format. It will just take every byte of the binary file you uploaded and write it as the image “bitmap”. You then need to attach an image decoder that will parse that bitmap and generate the real, renderable bitmap.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{header.cf}} will be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_ALPHA}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_CHROME\_KEYED}} accordingly. You should choose the correct format according to your needs: fully opaque image, use alpha channel or use chroma keying.

After decoding, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{raw} formats are considered \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} by the library. In other words, the image decoder must decode the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} images to \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} according to the format described in {[}\#color-formats{]}(Color formats) section.

If you want to create a custom image, you should use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_USER\_ENCODED\_0..7}} color formats. However, the library can draw the images only in \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} format (or \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} but finally it’s supposed to be in \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} format).
So the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_USER\_ENCODED\_...}} formats are not known by the library, therefore, they should be decoded to one of the known formats from {[}\#color-formats{]}(Color formats) section.
It’s possible to decode the image to a non-true color format first, for example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_INDEXED\_4BITS}}, and then call the built-in decoder functions to convert it to \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color}.

With \sphinxstyleemphasis{User encoded} formats, the color format in the open function (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}header.cf}}) should be changed according to the new format.


\subparagraph{Enregistrer un décodeur d’image}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:enregistrer-un-decodeur-d-image}}
Here’s an example of getting LittlevGL to work with PNG images.

First, you need to create a new image decoder and set some functions to open/close the PNG files. It should looks like this:

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dec} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dec}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{decoder\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dec}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Obtient les informations sur une image PNG}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointeur vers le décodeur auquel cette fonction appartient}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param src peut être un nom de fichier ou un pointeur sur un tableau C}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param header enregistre l\PYGZsq{}information ici}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @returnLV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK : pas d\PYGZsq{}erreur ; LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV : impossible d\PYGZsq{}obtenir l\PYGZsq{}information}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}info}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{src}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}header\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Vérifie si le type {}`src{}` est connu du décodeur */}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Read the PNG header and find {}`width{}` and {}`height{}` */}
  \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

  \PYG{n}{header}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{height}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Ouvre une image PNG et retourne l\PYGZsq{}image décodée}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointeur vers le décodeur auquel cette fonction appartient}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param dsc pointeur sur le descripteur de cette session de décodage}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @returnLV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK : pas d\PYGZsq{}erreur ; LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV : impossible d\PYGZsq{}obtenir l\PYGZsq{}information}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Vérifie si le type {}`src{}` est connu du décodeur */}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{is\PYGZus{}png}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{src}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Decode and store the image. If {}`dsc\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}img\PYGZus{}data{}` is {}`NULL{}`, the {}`read\PYGZus{}line{}` function will be called to get the image data line\PYGZhy{}by\PYGZhy{}line*/}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}

\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointeur vers le décodeur associé à la fonction }
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param dsc pointeur vers le descripteur de décodeur}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param x coordonnée x de début}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param y coordonnée y de début}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}built\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}line}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}coord\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}

\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointeur vers le décodeur auquel cette fonction appartient}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param dsc pointeur sur le descripteur de cette session de décodage}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Libère toutes les données allouées */}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Appelle la fonction intégrée de fermeture si les fonctions intégrées open/read\PYGZus{}line ont été utilisées */}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}built\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

Donc en résumé :
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_info}}, you should collect some basic information about the image and store it in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{header}}.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_open}}, you should try to open the image source pointed by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}src}}. Its type is already in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}src\_type == LV\_IMG\_SRC\_FILE/VARIABLE}}.
If this format/type is not supported by the decoder, return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_RES\_INV}}.
However, if you can open the image, a pointer to the decoded \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} image should be set in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data}}.
If the format is known but, you don’t want to decode while image (e.g. no memory for it) set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data = NULL}} to call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_line}} to get the pixels.

\item {} 
Dans \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_close}}, vous devez libérer toutes les ressources allouées.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_read}} is optional. Decoding the whole image requires extra memory and some computational overhead.
However, if can decode one line of the image without decoding the whole image, you can save memory and time.
To indicate that, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line read} function should be used, set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data = NULL}} in the open function.

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Utiliser manuellement un décodeur d’image}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:utiliser-manuellement-un-decodeur-d-image}}
LittlevGL will use the registered image decoder automatically if you try and draw a raw image (i.e. using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img}} object) but you can use them manually too. Create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_dsc\_t}} variable to describe the decoding session and call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_open()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_open()}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}plain}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Faites quelque chose avec {}`dsc\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}img\PYGZus{}data{}` */}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Mise en cache des images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:mise-en-cache-des-images}}
Sometimes it takes a lot of time to open an image.
Continuously decoding a PNG image or loading images from a slow external memory would be inefficient and detrimental to the user experience.

Therefore, LittlevGL caches a given number of images. Caching means some images will be left open, hence LittlevGL can quickly access them from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data}} instead of needing to decode them again.

Of course, caching images is resource-intensive as it uses more RAM (to store the decoded image). LittlevGL tries to optimize the process as much as possible (see below), but you will still need to evaluate if this would be beneficial for your platform or not. If you have a deeply embedded target which decodes small images from a relatively fast storage medium, image caching may not be worth it.


\subparagraph{Taille du cache}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:taille-du-cache}}
The number of cache entries can be defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CACHE\_DEF\_SIZE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. The default value is 1 so only the most recently used image will be left open.

The size of the cache can be changed at run-time with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_cache\_set\_size(entry\_num)}}.


\subparagraph{Valeur des images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:valeur-des-images}}
When you use more images than cache entries, LittlevGL can’t cache all of the images. Instead, the library will close one of the cached images (to free space).

To decide which image to close, LittlevGL uses a measurement it previously made of how long it took to open the image. Cache entries that hold slower-to-open images are considered more valuable and are kept in the cache as long as possible.

If you want or need to override LittlevGL’s measurement, you can manually set the \sphinxstyleemphasis{time to open} value in the decoder open function in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}time\_to\_open = time\_ms}} to give a higher or lower value. (Leave it unchanged to let LittlevGL set it.)

Every cache entry has a \sphinxstyleemphasis{“life”} value. Every time an image opening happens through the cache, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{life} of all entries are decreased to make them older.
When a cached image is used, its \sphinxstyleemphasis{life} is increased by the \sphinxstyleemphasis{time to open} value to make it more alive.

If there is no more space in the cache, always the entry with the smallest life will be closed.


\subparagraph{Utilisation de la mémoire}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:utilisation-de-la-memoire}}
Note that, the cached image might continuously consume memory. For example, if 3 PNG images are cached, they will consume memory while they are opened.

Therefore, it’s the user’s responsibility to be sure there is enough RAM to cache, even the largest images at the same time.


\subparagraph{Nettoyer le cache}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:nettoyer-le-cache}}
Let’s say you have loaded a PNG image into a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t my\_png}} variable and use it in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img}} object. If the image is already cached and you then change the underlying PNG file, you need to notify LittlevGL to cache the image again. Otherwise, there is no easy way of detecting that the underlying file changed and LittlevGL will still draw the old image.

To do this, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_cache\_invalidate\_src(\&my\_png)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is passed as a parameter, the whole cache will be cleaned.

\subsubsection{Système de fichiers}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:systeme-de-fichiers}}\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}}
LittlevGL has a ‘File system’ abstraction module that enables you to attach any type of file systems.
The file system is identified by a drive letter.
For example, if the SD card is associated with the letter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'S'}}, a file can be reached like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"S:path/to/file.txt"}}.


\paragraph{Ajouter un pilote}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:ajouter-un-pilote}}
To add a driver, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_drv\_t}} needs to be initialized like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/* Initialisation de base */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{letter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+sc}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+sc}{S}\PYG{l+s+sc}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{;}                         \PYG{c+cm}{/* Une lettre majuscule pour identifier le lecteur */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{sizeof}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/* Taille requise pour enregistrer un objet de fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{rddir\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{sizeof}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Size required to store a directory object (used by dir\PYGZus{}open/close/read)*/}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{ready\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour indiquer si le lecteur est prêt à être utilisé */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{open\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour ouvrir un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{close\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour fermer un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour lire un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{write\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}write\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour écrire un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{seek\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}seek\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour se déplacer dans un fichier (déplacer le curseur) */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{tell\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}tell\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour donner la position du curseur */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{trunc\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}trunc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour supprimer un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{size\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}size\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour donner la taille d\PYGZsq{}un fichier */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{rename\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}size\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour renommer un fichier */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour ouvrir un répertoire et lire son contenu */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour lire le contenu d\PYGZsq{}un répertoire */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}       \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour fermer un répertoire */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{free\PYGZus{}space\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}size\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}           \PYG{c+cm}{/* Fonction de rappel pour donner l\PYGZsq{}espace libre d\PYGZsq{}un lecteur */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/* Toute donnée personnalisée si nécessaire */}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/* Finalement enregistre le lecteur */}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Any of the callbacks can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} to indicate that that operation is not supported.

As an example of how the callbacks are used, if you use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_open(\&file, "S:/folder/file.txt", LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR)}}, LittlevGL:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Verifies that a registered drive exists with the letter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'S'}}.

\item {} 
Checks if it’s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{open\_cb}} is implemented (not \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}).

\item {} 
Calls the set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{open\_cb}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"folder/file.txt"}} path.

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Exemple d’utilisation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:exemple-d-utilisation}}
L’exemple ci-dessous montre comment lire à partir d’un fichier :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}}\PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}handling}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{Le mode dans \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_open}} peut être \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR}} pour ouvrir en écriture ou \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FS\_MODE\_RD \textbar{} LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR}} pour lecture/écriture}

\paragraph{Utiliser les pilotes pour les images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:utiliser-les-pilotes-pour-les-images}}
{\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} objects can be opened from files too (besides variables stored in the flash).

To initialize the image, the following callbacks are required:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
open

\item {} 
close

\item {} 
read

\item {} 
seek

\item {} 
tell

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Animations}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:animations}}\label{\detokenize{overview/animation::doc}}
You can automatically change the value of a variable between a start and an end value using animations.
L’animation est réalisée par l’appel périodique d’une fonction “animateur” avec comme paramètre la valeur correspondante.

La fonction “animateur” a la signature suivante :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{func}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{var}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}var\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Cette signature est compatible avec la plupart des fonctions \sphinxstyleemphasis{set} de LittlevGL. Par exemple \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x(obj, value)}} ou \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width(obj, value)}}


\paragraph{Créer une animation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:creer-une-animation}}
Pour créer une animation, une variable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_t}} doit être initialisée et configurée avec les fonctions \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_set\_...()}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}exec\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the animator function and variable to animate*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{duration}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{delay}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}values}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{end}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit les valeurs initiale et finale. P. ex. 0, 150 */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}linear}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit le chemin à partir d\PYGZsq{}une des fonctions {}`lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}...{}` ou d\PYGZsq{}une fonction spécifique. */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/* Définit une fonction de rappel à exécuter quand l\PYGZsq{}animation est prête (optionnel). */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}playback}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/* Active le déroulé de l\PYGZsq{}animation après un délai {}`wait\PYGZus{}time{}` */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}repeat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}              \PYG{c+cm}{/* Active la répétition d\PYGZsq{}une animation après un délai {}`wait\PYGZus{}time{}`. Peut être associé à la fonction {}`lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}playback{}`*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                             \PYG{c+cm}{/* Débute l\PYGZsq{}animation */}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

You can apply \sphinxstylestrong{multiple different animations} on the same variable at the same time.
For example, animate the x and y coordinates with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_y}}. However, only one animation can exist with a given variable and function pair.
Therefore \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_create()}} will delete the already existing variable-function animations.


\paragraph{Chemin d’animation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:chemin-d-animation}}
You can determinate the \sphinxstylestrong{path of animation}. In the most simple case, it is linear, which means the current value between \sphinxstyleemphasis{start} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{end}  is changed linearly.
A \sphinxstyleemphasis{path} is a function which calculates the next value to set based on the current state of the animation. Currently, there are the following built-in paths:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_linear} animation linéaire

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_step} change en une seule fois à la fin

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_in} lent au début

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_out} lent à la fin

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_in\_out} lent au début et à la fin

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_overshoot} dépasse la valeur finale

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_bounce} bounce back a little from the end value (like hitting a wall)

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Vitesse et durée}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:vitesse-et-duree}}
By default, you can set the animation time. But, in some cases, the \sphinxstylestrong{animation speed} is more practical.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_speed\_to\_time(speed, start, end)}} function calculates the required time in milliseconds to reach the end value from a start value with the given speed.
The speed is interpreted in \sphinxstyleemphasis{unit/sec} dimension. For example,  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_speed\_to\_time(20,0,100)}} will give 5000 milliseconds. For example, in case of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x}} \sphinxstyleemphasis{unit} is pixels so \sphinxstyleemphasis{20} means \sphinxstyleemphasis{20 px/sec} speed.


\paragraph{Supprimer des animations}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:supprimer-des-animations}}
Vous pouvez \sphinxstylestrong{supprimer une animation} par \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_del(var, func)}} en indiquant la variable animée et sa fonction animateur.

\subsubsection{Tâches}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:taches}}\label{\detokenize{overview/task::doc}}
LittlevGL has a built-in task system. You can register a function to have it be called periodically. The tasks are handled and called in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}}, which needs to be called periodically every few milliseconds.
Voir {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Portage}}}} pour plus d’informations.

The tasks are non-preemptive, which means a task cannot interrupt another task. Therefore, you can call any LittlevGL related function in a task.


\paragraph{Créer une tâche}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:creer-une-tache}}
To create a new task, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_create(task\_cb, period\_ms, LV\_TASK\_PRIO\_OFF/LOWEST/LOW/MID/HIGH/HIGHEST, user\_data)}}. It will create an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_t *}} variable, which can be used later to modify the parameters of the task.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_create\_basic()}} can also be used. It allows you to create a new task without specifying any parameters.

La fonction de rappel d’une tâche doit avoir la signature \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{void (* lv\_task\_cb\_t)(lv\_task\_t *)}}.

Par exemple :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Utilise les données de l\PYGZsq{}utilisateur */}
  \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}

\paragraph{Exécution et réinitialisation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:execution-et-reinitialisation}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_ready(task)}} fait exécuter la tâche lors du prochain appel de \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_reset(task)}} resets the period of a task. It will be called again after the defined period of milliseconds has elapsed.


\paragraph{Paramètres}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:parametres}}
Vous pouvez modifier ultérieurement certains paramètres des tâches :
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_cb(task, new\_cb)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_period(task, new\_period)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_prio(task, new\_priority)}}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Tâches uniques}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:taches-uniques}}
You can make a task to run only once by calling\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_once(task)}}. The task will automatically be deleted after being called for the first time.


\paragraph{Mesurer le temps d’inactivité}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:mesurer-le-temps-d-inactivite}}
You can get the idle percentage time \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_get\_idle()}}. Note that, it doesn’t measure the idle time of the overall system, only \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}.
It can be misleading if you use an operating system and call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} in an  task, as it won’t actually measure the time the OS spends in an idle thread.


\paragraph{Appels asynchrones}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:appels-asynchrones}}
In some cases, you can’t do an action immediately. For example, you can’t delete an object right now because something else is still using it or you don’t want to block the execution now.
For these cases, you can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_async\_call(my\_function, data\_p)}} to make \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_function}} be called on the next call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_p}} will be passed to function when it’s called.
Notez que seul le pointeur des données est enregistré. Vous devez donc vous assurer que la variable sera “à portée” lors de l’appel de la fonction. Pour cela, vous pouvez utiliser des données \sphinxstyleemphasis{statiques}, globales ou allouées dynamiquement.

Par exemple :

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}screen\PYGZus{}clean\PYGZus{}up}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Libére des ressources liées à {}`scr{}` */}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Au final supprime l\PYGZsq{}écran */}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}del}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* Fait quelque chose avec l\PYGZsq{}objet sur l\PYGZsq{}écran courant */}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* Supprime l\PYGZsq{}écran lors du prochain appel de {}`lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler{}`. Donc pas maintenant. */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}async\PYGZus{}call}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}screen\PYGZus{}clean\PYGZus{}up}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* L\PYGZsq{}écran est toujours valide donc vous pouvez faire d\PYGZsq{}autres choses avec */}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If you just want to delete an object, and don’t need to clean anything up in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_screen\_cleanup}}, you could just use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del\_async}}, which will delete the object on the next call to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}.
